item.title: Test Automation for Web Applications
item.description:
Why Automation:

Web-based applications are growing. These applications are very interactive and responsive and run on many platforms. So automation becomes essential for faster releases which is a need for agile process.

Advantages of Automation:
1. Fast: Runs tests significantly faster than human users.
2. Repeatable: Testers can test how the website or software reacts after repeated execution of the same operation.
3. Run many times: Frequent regression testing
4. Faster results: Rapid feedback to developers
5. Run unlimited times: Virtually unlimited iterations of test case execution
6. Works in all processes: Support for Agile and extreme development methodologies
7. Documentation: Disciplined documentation of test cases
8. Auto Defect Report: Customized defect reporting
9. Comprehensive Coverage: Testers can build test suites of tests that covers every feature in software application. This helps in finding defects missed by manual testing

item.title: Introducing Selenium
item.description:
1. It is a set of many software tools to perform test automation
2. Entire suite of tools helps QA to automate web applications (note cannot automate native desktop apps)
3. This tools help in locating user interface elements, performing action on it and then verifying the expected results with actual results
4. Key feature of Selenium is QA can create test once and run it on multiple browsers

item.title: Brief History of The Selenium Project
item.description:
A Story of Marriage

Who did it and what was done:


1. First Creator: Jason Huggins
2. First developed as a javascript library to interact with the web page and run tests against multiple browser
3. The Javascript library created became Selenium Core(now it contains all functionality of RC and IDE)
4. The above library could control a browser from the language of our choice

Why there was a need for more:


1. Since the library for automation was Javascript based, the security limitations provided by the browser against javascript resulted in limiting the power of the
library.
2. Web Applications became more powerful with newer features that are native to browser. Using external javascript programs to automate/control browser became more
difficult

Who came for help:


1. Simon Stewart from google came up with WebDriver project that could solve many of the problems
2. WebDriver can speak directly to browser using native methods of browser(no sandbox)
3. In 2008, Selenium and webdriver got married :)
